name: vector
description: Vector is a tool for building observability pipelines.

subcommands.name: vector convert-config
subcommands.description: Convert a config file from one format to another. This command can also walk directories recursively and convert all config files that are discovered. Note that this is a best effort conversion due to the following reasons: * The comments from the original config file are not preserved. * Explicitly set default values in the original implementation might be omitted. * Depending on how each source/sink config struct configures serde, there might be entries with null values

options.description: Print help
The target format to which existing config files will be converted to

subcommands.name: vector generate
subcommands.description: Generate a Vector configuration containing a list of components

options.description: Generate config as a file
Output format
Whether to skip the generation of global fields
Print help (see a summary with '-h')

subcommands.name: vector generate-schema
subcommands.description: Generate the configuration schema for this version of Vector. (experimental)

options.description: Print help (see a summary with '-h')

subcommands.name: vector graph
subcommands.description: Output the topology as visual representation using the DOT language which can be rendered by GraphViz

options.description: Read configuration from one or more files. Wildcard paths are supported. File format is detected from the file name. If zero files are specified the default config path `/etc/vector/vector.yaml` will be targeted
Read configuration from files in one or more directories. File format is detected from the file name. Files not ending in .toml, .json, .yaml, or .yml will be ignored.
Vector config files in JSON format
Vector config files in TOML format
Vector config files in YAML format
Print help (see a summary with '-h')
Format the list in an encoding scheme
Print help

subcommands.name: vector tap
subcommands.description: Observe output log events from source or transform components. Logs are sampled at a specified interval

options.description: Specifies a duration (in milliseconds) to sample logs (e.g. specifying 10000 will sample logs for 10 seconds then exit)
Encoding format for events printed to screen
Print help
Components (transforms, sinks) IDs whose inputs to observe (comma-separated; accepts glob patterns)
Interval to sample logs at, in milliseconds
Maximum number of events to sample each interval
Include metadata such as the event's associated component ID
Whether to reconnect if the underlying API connection drops. By default, tap will attempt to reconnect if the connection drops
Components (sources, transforms) IDs whose outputs to observe (comma-separated; accepts glob patterns)
Quiet output includes only events
GraphQL API server endpoint

subcommands.name: vector test
subcommands.description: Run Vector config unit tests, then exit. This command is experimental and therefore subject to change. For guidance on how to write unit tests check out <https://vector.dev/guides/level-up/unit-testing/>

options.description: Vector config files in JSON format to test
Vector config files in TOML format to test
Vector config files in YAML format to test
Read configuration from files in one or more directories. File format is detected from the file name. Files not ending in .toml, .json, .yaml, or .yml will be ignored.
Print help (see a summary with '-h')

subcommands.name: vector top
subcommands.description: Display topology and metrics in the console, for a local or remote Vector instance

options.description: Print help (see a summary with '-h')
Humanize metrics, using numeric suffixes - e.g. 1,100 = 1.10 k, 1,000,000 = 1.00 M
Interval to sample metrics at, in milliseconds
Whether to reconnect if the underlying API connection drops. By default, top will attempt to reconnect if the connection drops.
GraphQL API server endpoint

subcommands.name: vector validate
subcommands.description: Validate the target config, then exit

options.description: Vector config files in JSON format to validate
Vector config files in TOML format to validate
Vector config files in YAML format to validate
Disables environment checks. That includes component checks and health checks
Disables health checks during validation
Read configuration from files in one or more directories. File format is detected from the file name. Files not ending in .toml, .json, .yaml, or .yml will be ignored.
Fail validation on warnings that are probably a mistake in the configuration or are recommended to be fixed
Print help (see a summary with '-h')

subcommands.name: vector vrl
subcommands.description: A command-line interface for executing VRL programs with various options.

options.description: Print help
The file containing the event object(s) to handle. JSON events should be one per line.
Print the (modified) event object instead of the result of the final expression. Setting this flag is equivalent to using `.` as the final expression.
Print warnings
The file containing the VRL program to execute. This can be used instead of `PROGRAM`
Should we use the VM to evaluate the VRL
The timezone used to parse dates

Allow the configuration to run without any components. This is useful for loading in an empty stub config that will later be replaced with actual components. Note that this is likely not useful without also watching for config file changes as described in `--watch-config`
Set runtime allocation tracing
Set allocation tracing reporting rate in milliseconds

Read configuration from one or more files. Wildcard paths are supported. File format is detected from the file name. If zero files are specified, the deprecated default config path `/etc/vector/vector.yaml` is targeted
Read configuration from files in one or more directories. File format is detected from the file name. Files not ending in .toml, .json, .yaml, or .yml will be ignored.
Read configuration from one or more files. Wildcard paths are supported. JSON file format is expected
Read configuration from one or more files. Wildcard paths are supported. TOML file format is expected
Read configuration from one or more files. Wildcard paths are supported. YAML file format is expected

Control when ANSI terminal formatting is used. By default `vector` will try and detect if `stdout` is a terminal, if it is ANSI will be enabled. Otherwise it will be disabled. By providing this flag with the `--color always` option will always enable ANSI terminal formatting. `--color never` will disable all ANSI terminal formatting. `--color auto` will attempt to detect it automatically.

Set the duration in seconds to wait for graceful shutdown after SIGINT or SIGTERM are received. After the duration has passed, Vector will force shutdown. To never force shutdown, use `--no-graceful-shutdown-limit`
Print help (see a summary with '-h')
Set the internal log rate limit
Set the logging format

Never time out while waiting for graceful shutdown after SIGINT or SIGTERM received. This is useful when you would like for Vector to attempt to send data until terminated by a SIGKILL. Overrides/cannot be set with `--graceful-shutdown-limit-secs`

Disable probing and configuration of root certificate locations on the system for OpenSSL. The probe functionality manipulates the `SSL_CERT_FILE` and `SSL_CERT_DIR` environment variables in the Vector process. This behavior can be problematic for users of the `exec` source, which by default inherits the environment of the Vector process.
Reduce detail of internal logging. Repeat to reduce further. Overrides `--verbose`
Exit on startup if any sinks fail healthchecks
Number of threads to use for processing (default is number of available cores)
Enable more detailed internal logging. Repeat to increase level. Overridden by `--quiet`
Print version
Watch for changes in configuration file, and reload accordingly

Method for configuration watching. By default, `vector` uses recommended watcher for host OS - `inotify` for Linux-based systems. - `kqueue` for unix/macos - `ReadDirectoryChangesWatcher` for windows. The `poll` watcher can be used in cases where `inotify` doesn't work, e.g., when attaching the configuration via NFS.
Poll for changes in the configuration file at the given interval. This setting is only applicable if `Poll` is set in `--watch-config-method`.
